title: 109_hr5973
content: The "Hydrogen Transportation Wins Over Growing Reliance on Oil (H2 GROW) Act" provides a credit for the installation of hydrogen fueling stations under the new section 30D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Hydrogen Transportation Wins Over Growing Reliance on Oil (H2 GROW) Act" offers a 50% tax credit for expenses on qualified hydrogen-powered vehicle refueling property installation. The credit is applicable in the year the property is put into service by the taxpayer. Qualified property must be depreciable and have its original use with the taxpayer. The "Hydrogen Transportation Wins Over Growing Reliance on Oil (H2 GROW) Act" provides a 50% tax credit for hydrogen-powered vehicle refueling property installation. The property must be used for hydrogen fuel production, storage, or dispensing at a taxpayer's facility for public vehicle fueling. The credit cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by other applicable credits, and the property's cost reduces its basis for tax purposes. The tax credit for hydrogen-powered vehicle refueling property installation under the "Hydrogen Transportation Wins Over Growing Reliance on Oil (H2 GROW) Act" can be carried forward for 20 years if it exceeds the limitation for the current year. No double benefit is allowed if a credit is already claimed for the property under subsection (a). Special rules apply for the credit carryforward. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for the provisions of this section, with special rules applying. The section will not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2013. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1016(a) and 55(c)(2) of the Code. Subchapter A of chapter 1 is amended by adding a new item after section 30C. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service in taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is an exclusion of earnings from hydrogen fuel sales under a new section in the Internal Revenue Code. The exclusion of income from the sale of hydrogen fuel for use in hydrogen vehicles is defined in the Internal Revenue Code. This exclusion applies to sales before December 31, 2014. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new item after section 136. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new section 136A regarding income from hydrogen fuel sales, effective for income received after December 31, 2004, in taxable years ending after that date.
